text:
As per http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-revocation-05

Is not really a grant type and likely better served as a self sustained endpoint. Worth investigating spec maturity before implementing.
title: OAuth 2 Server - Token revocation

text: Initial version done in https://github.com/idan/oauthlib/commit/da775de8eea28299fa2ff74f625773d7a250a421 and documented at http://oauthlib.readthedocs.org/en/latest/oauth2/endpoints/revocation.html. Will try it out in "the wild" before closing.

Now RFC 7009.
Implementation should be updated.
Cool! Will have a look through for differences after my thesis is submitted mid Sept.

We not always need 
https://github.com/idan/oauthlib/blob/62ee76f22e8b0a53b2eda4a88e2891ed6578083b/oauthlib/oauth2/rfc6749/endpoints/revocation.py#L123
client authifiaction.

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7009#section-2.1
" The authorization server first validates the client credentials (in
case of a confidential client) and then verifies whether the token
was issued to the client making the revocation request."

if i have public application, we should skip "authenticate_client".
@ib-lundgren Can you describe the changes between your implementation and RFC 7009?
